title: 114_hr5267
content: The "Fighting Medicare Fraud Act of 2016" allows for expanded exclusion from federal health programs for individuals with prior interest in sanctioned entities and entities affiliated with sanctioned entities. Paragraph (15) of section 1128(b) of the Social Security Act is amended to include individuals and entities affiliated with a sanctioned entity who have ownership or control interests and were aware of any conduct that led to conviction or exclusion. The amended paragraph (15) of section 1128(b) of the Social Security Act includes individuals and entities affiliated with a sanctioned entity who have ownership or control interests and were aware of conduct leading to conviction or exclusion. A sanctioned entity is defined as an entity convicted of certain offenses or excluded from participation. The amended paragraph (15) of section 1128(b) of the Social Security Act defines an affiliated entity as one connected to a sanctioned entity through ownership or control interests, and includes individuals aware of conduct leading to conviction or exclusion. The amended paragraph (15) of section 1128(b) of the Social Security Act defines an affiliated entity as one connected to a sanctioned entity through ownership or control interests, including individuals aware of conduct leading to conviction or exclusion. This includes situations where a person with an ownership or control interest in an entity also has such an interest in a sanctioned entity, or where an officer or managing employee of an entity holds the same position in a sanctioned entity. The term 'an ownership or control interest' is defined in section 1124(a)(3) of the Social Security Act. SEC. 3 amends the Social Security Act to impose criminal penalties for illegal distribution of Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP beneficiary identification or provider numbers. Whoever knowingly purchases, sells, or distributes two or more beneficiary identification numbers for healthcare providers can face imprisonment for up to 15 years or fines. SEC. 4 requires reports on fraud and abuse under Medicare Parts C and D. The Social Security Act is amended to require MA organizations offering MA plans to report instances of fraud and abuse related to health benefits within 60 days. The Secretary will provide guidance within 90 days of enactment. The Social Security Act is amended to require MA organizations to report fraud and abuse related to health benefits within 60 days. Guidance for defining 'fraud' and 'abuse' will be issued to MA organizations and PDP sponsors. A conforming amendment to Part D is made, and the effective date for the amendments is plan years beginning on or after the enactment of the Act.
